block.p: A fight involving 300 inmates, apparently over a stolen gold chain, erupted on Monday evening at the state prison in Gouverneur, N.Y., leaving about 13 injured, one seriously, officials said yesterday.

The fight at the medium-security prison, about 25 miles from the Canadian border, pitted a group of black inmates against a group of Hispanic prisoners. But officials refused to characterize the upheaval as racial. James Flateau, a spokesman for the Department of Correctional Services, said the incident was still under investigation and would not comment on a possible cause.

A fight involving 300 inmates, apparently over a stolen gold chain, erupted on Monday evening at the state prison in Gouverneur, N.Y., leaving about 13 injured, one seriously, officials said yesterday.

The fight at the medium-security prison, about 25 miles from the Canadian border, pitted a group of black inmates against a group of Hispanic prisoners. But officials refused to characterize the upheaval as racial. James Flateau, a spokesman for the Department of Correctional Services, said the incident was still under investigation and would not comment on a possible cause.

But a correction official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the fight may have been ignited when a black inmate tried to steal a gold chain from a Hispanic inmate. Mr. Flateau would not confirm or deny this explanation.
He said the 890-inmate prison, while at capacity, was not overcrowded. Although the prison was over capacity several years ago, Mr. Flateau said the numbers had been brought down two years ago.
By last night, all the inmates except those injured were back in their dormitories and were being fed in the mess.

The fight began about 7:30 P.M. in the prison yard. The state police, called in to guard the edge of the prison, did not leave until 3 A.M. By then, one inmate had been critically injured by a blow to the head, Mr. Flateau said. His condition was upgraded to guarded yesterday, and a half-dozen of the injured remained hospitalized with cuts and fractures.
Several guards suffered from inhaling a substance like tear gas, used to control the inmates, and two suffered minor injuries.
Mr. Flateau characterized the incident as isolated, "to the extent it was unrelated to anything happening at any other prison," he said.
